content.heading: Introduction
copy: The head of an HTML document is the part that is not displayed in the web browser when the page is loaded. It contains information such as the page <title> and metadata (data about the document, such as keywords and character encoding).
Metadata is the data the describes data. Within HTML, metadata is added to a document using the <meta> tag.
Many <meta> tags include name and content attributes:

• name specifies the type of meta tag it is; what type of information it contains.
  • content specifies the actual meta content.

content.heading: Character Encoding
copy: This meta tag basically specifies what character set your document is written in. UTF-8 (Universal character set Transformation Format 8 bit) is the most common character set used and is a character encoding capable of encoding all possible characters in Unicode. This encoding is variable-length and uses 8-bit code units. UTF-8 also allows us to write text in all kinds of languages and pretty much includes any character from any human language. For example, using character encoding would allow your page to handle English and Japanese.
The charset attribute specifies the character encoding for an HTML document. This is an HTML5 attribute, although the previous HTML 4.01 meta tag can still be used if required.
If you set your character encoding to ISO-8859-1, for example (the character set for the Latin alphabet), your page rendering may appear all messed up.
This meta tag should be the first tag placed within the <head> section of your HTML document.
content.label: CODE/MARKUP

content.heading: X-UI-Compatible
copy: The X-UA-Compatible meta tage allows web authors to choose what version of Internet Explorer the page should be rendered as. According to Microsoft, when using the X-UA-Compatible tag, it should be as high as possible in your document <head>
Internet Explorer (IE) begins interpreting markup using the latest version. When Internet Explorer encounters the X-UA-Compatible meta tag, it starts over using the designated version's engine.

Depending upon what Microsoft browsers you support, you may need to continue to use the X-UA-Compatible tag. If you need to support IE9 or IE8, then continue to use the meta tag. If you only need to support the latest browsers - IE11 and/or Edge - then the tag is not needed.

Starting with IE11, Edge mode is the preferred document mode and represents the highest support for modern standards available to the browser. Edge mode was introduced in IE8 and has been available in each subsequent release. Features supported in Edge mode are limited to those supported by the specific version of the browser that is rendering the content.

Document modes are deprecated in IE11/Edge and should no longer be used. If you currently use this meta tag to target a legacy document mode, such as IE8, it's possible your site won't reflect the best experience available with IE11.

SECTION
copy: Edge mode tells Internet Explorer (IE) to display content in the highest mode available. With IE9, this is equivalent to IE9 mode. If a future release of IE supported a higher compatibility mode, pages set to edge mode would appear in the highest mode supported by that version. Those same pages would still appear in IE9 mode when viewed within IE9.
Using Edge mode will basically use the latest version of IE and not use 'Compatibility mode'.
Changing the compatibility mode can affect the way content is displayed.

content.heading: Refresh
copy: The refresh meta tag defines a time interval for the document to refresh itself. This value should be used carefully as it takes control of the page away from the user. Using 'refresh' will cause a failure in the W3C's WCAG 2.0 (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) - Level A. A document must not use 'refresh' because it can prevent control over when the refresh occurs for users with disabilities.

The most common use of this tag is to reload the page that contains dynamic content, such as a stock ticker or weather map. Ultimately, there are better ways to refresh page content without needing to actually use a meta tag to refresh the entire page.
Refreshing the page automatically may cause confusion to users and a frustrating user experience. A refresh will also move focus back to the top of the page.
It is better to use a server-side 301 redirect instead of this meta tag, should you need to redirect users elsewhere.

content.heading: Description & Search Engines
copy: Search Engines use the description meta tag on their search results pages. When search results are displayed, often the page title and the content within the description meta tag will be shown.

In Google, you may see relevant subpages listed below the main homepage link. These are called sitelinks, and can be configured within Google's webmaster tools. These help to make your site's search results better within Google.
Use this meta tag to include text you want to appear in search results.

content.heading: Keywords
copy: The keyword <meta> tag was used to provide keywords for search engines to determine relevance of that page for different search terms. This is no-longer used by search engines as it was misused by spammers using the meta tag to fill the keyword list with hundreds of keywords, causing bias results. This is known as 'keyword stuffing'. Google no-longer uses meta keywords in it's ranking algorithm at all, because of this ease of abuse.
This meta tag should no longer be used in your HTML.
content.label: CODE/MARKUP
code: <meta name="keywords" content="fill, in, your, keywords, here" />

content.heading: Open Graph (OG) Data
copy: Open Graph (OG) Data is a metadata protocol created by Facebook to provide richer metadata for websites. When using OG, should you post the link to your website to the social network, the link appears along with an image and description. This provides a richer user experience.
Twitter has it's own similar proprietary metadata, which has a similar effect when the site's URL is displayed on Twitter.
